I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Democratic  Socialist  Republic  of  Sri  Lanka  for  the  Local  Government  Enhancement 
Sector Project.1 The report also describes proposed capacity development technical assistance 
(TA) for Local Government Service Enhancement, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, 
I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 

 
2. 
The  outcome  of  the  project  will  be  improved  local  infrastructure  and  services  delivered 
effectively  by  local  authorities  in  less-developed  areas  of  Sri  Lanka.  Under  the  project,  about 
100  local  authorities  selected  in  seven  provinces  (excluding  the  Northern  and  Eastern 
provinces), whose reform plans are reviewed and confirmed by the government, will implement 
subprojects  for  roads  and  bridges,  water  supply  and  sanitation,  drainage,  solid  waste 
management, and other basic facilities, including building or enhancing health-care centers and 
public markets. The project will support the institutional strengthening of the local authorities for 
improved  and  sustainable  service  delivery  through  business  process  reengineering  and  the 
development of their information technology (IT) systems.2  

 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
3. 
The  government’s  development  policy  framework  highlights  the  need  for  balanced 
regional  development  to  ensure  that  every  household  in  Sri  Lanka  benefits  equally  from 
economic  development. 3  It  stresses  the  need  to  channel  more  resources  to  the  poorer 
segments of the population to rectify rural–urban imbalances and improve access to social and 
economic infrastructure including transport, drinking water supply, and public health care. While 
the  urban  population  is  growing  at  3.0%  per  annum  and  is  expected  to  encompass  half  the 
country’s total population by 2016, there is a large infrastructure deficit in peri-urban and small 
townships  in  rural  areas.  Current  local  service  deficiencies  include  (i)  intermittent  or  limited 
water  supply  services  in  many  townships;  (ii)  dilapidated  local  roads  that  hamper  connectivity 
and economic and social activities; (iii) haphazard solid waste management that includes a lack 
of suitable landfill sites, causing nuisance and public health risks; (iv) limited primary health-care 
facilities; (v) inadequate drainage, causing waterlogging in township areas; and (vi) inadequate 
public  market  facilities  that  hinder  local  economic  activity.  While  poverty  affects  the  general 
population  in  lagging  regions,  the  economic  and  social  activities  of  women  are  severely 
constrained  by  poor  infrastructure  and  services.  Poverty  is  concentrated  in  areas  where 
connectivity to towns and markets is relatively low.4 Improving infrastructure and service delivery 
standards  in  these  areas  is  constrained  by  the  limited  financial,  technical,  and  management 
capacity  of  local  authorities  responsible  for  local  service  delivery  under  a  decentralized 
administrative system. 

 
4. 
Sri Lanka has three types of local authorities under nine provincial councils: (i) municipal 
councils constituted in cities and large towns, (ii) urban councils for less urbanized areas, and 
(iii)  pradeshiya  sabhas5 in  peri-urban  and  rural  areas.6 To  respond  to  the  needs  of  improving

approved  the  Local  Government  Infrastructure  Improvement  Project  (LGIIP)  in  2005. 7  In 
alignment  with  the  government's  devolved  structure,  local  authorities  are  implementing 
subprojects  for  water  supply,  roads,  drainage  and  sewerage,  and  other  municipal  facilities, 
including  constructing  or  renovating  public  libraries,  health-care  centers,  and  office  buildings. 
The LGIIP adopted a bottom–up, demand-driven approach that follows the priorities set out by 
local authorities and is being implemented successfully. Most, if not all, outcome indicators will 
be  achieved  by  project  completion,  along  with  improvement  in  the  financial  management 
capacity  of  local  authorities.  Unlike  the  common  practice  of  grant-based  financing  for  basic 
infrastructure  improvement,  partial  debt  financing  has  provided  local  authorities  with  stronger 
ownership and incentives to improve revenue collection and financial management.8 
 
One  limitation  of  the  LGIIP  is  that  poor  and  financially  weak  pradeshiya  sabhas  are 
5. 
unable to benefit because of their financial constraints. These local authorities are often located 
in  remote  areas;  have  very  small  revenue  bases,  if  any;  and  collect  very  limited  revenues 
through  assessment  taxes,  rental  fees,  and  licenses.  To  objectively  identify  less-developed 
areas  where  economic  and  social  infrastructure  and  services  are  limited  and  the  capacity  of 
pradeshiya  sabhas  is  weak,  the  Ministry  of  Local  Government  and  Provincial  Councils 
(MLGPC)  established  a  set  of  indicators  for  evaluating  pradeshiya  sabhas,  covering  (i) 
geographic  location  and  demography,  (ii)  social  infrastructure  and  quality  of  life,  (iii)  physical 
infrastructure  and  services,  (iv)  financial  strength  and  resources,  and  (v)  local  authority 
management  capacity. 9  Based  on  the  evaluation  results,  the  MLGPC  selected  about  100 
pradeshiya  sabhas  with  high  scores  (i.e.,  poor  infrastructure  with  weak  capacity)  in  seven

Many  development  partners  including  ADB  are  prioritizing  support  to the  Northern  and 
Eastern provinces, where reconstruction and development needs are high after the end of the 
armed  conflict  in  mid-2009.11 This  includes  grant  financing  to  all  local  authorities  in  the  two 
provinces  for  service  improvement.12 However,  poverty  is  found  not  only  in  the  Northern  and 
Eastern  provinces  but  in  other  provinces  as  well.  Districts  in  Sabaragamuwa,  Uva,  North 
Western, Southern, and Central provinces recorded a poverty headcount index higher than 10% 
in 2009/2010, while the national average dropped from 15.2% in 2006/2007 to 8.9%.13 Despite a 
decline  in  the  poverty  index  nationwide,  the  Gini-coefficient,  an  indicator  of  inequality,  has 
remained constant at 0.47 since 2002.14 There is a need to provide resources to less-developed 
areas of the country to help achieve balanced regional development.

7. 
Although  local governments  are  vested  with powers  regarding  various aspects  of  local 
administration,  including  the  provision  of  physical  infrastructure,  many  of  them,  particularly 
pradeshiya  sabhas,  face  a  number  of  challenges  in  exercising  their  powers  because  of  their 
limited own sources of revenue, resulting high dependence on fiscal transfers from the central 
government,  and  limited  technical  capacity  in  physical  planning,  implementing  infrastructure 
projects, and managing the assets created. Offices are hardly computerized and not operated 
in  an  efficient  and  citizen-friendly  manner.  Taxation,  licensing,  and  approval  systems  and 
processes  in  local  governments  leave  room  for  streamlining  to  attract  more  business.  The 
government  is  currently  reforming  the  local  government  system  through  amendments  to  acts 
and ordinances governing local government, with the aim of reengineering business processes, 
enhancing  citizen  participation,  expanding  local  authorities’  functions,  and  enhancing  revenue 
bases.15 Local infrastructure improvement will be most effective if it is implemented  along with 
reform in local government that strengthens its capacity. 

 
8. 
The  project  will  follow  a  sector  lending  modality.  Building  on  the  government 
development policy framework and the National Policy on Local Government adopted in 2009, 
the Local Government Development Plan, which is a medium-term sector development plan of 
the MLGPC, has been formulated.16 The plan has two pillars: (i) advancing the reform of local 
government  systems,  as  stated  above,  and  (ii)  improving  infrastructure  and  services, 
particularly  in  areas  with  deficient  services.  The  MLGPC  has  the  institutional  capacity  to 
implement  the  plan  with  support  provided  through  the  project  and  TA.  The  project  will  play  a 
key role in assisting the government in implementing both pillars of the plan and is expected to 
achieve  great  impact  toward  strengthening  the  financial  and  management  capacity  of  local 
authorities. 

 
Lessons  from  previous  projects  and  evaluation  in  Sri  Lanka  include  the  need  to  (i) 
9.

capacity-building  support  toward  handing  over  the  management  of  water  schemes  to  local 
authorities  and  community-based  organizations,  and  (iv)  incorporate  greater  consultation  and 
participatory  processes  into  project  design  and  implementation. 17 Lessons  learned  from  the 
ongoing LGIIP include the need to (i) integrate multiple subprojects in the same areas to create

Impact and Outcome 

B. 
 
11. 
The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  local  authorities’  capacity  financially  and  technically 
strengthened in less-developed areas of seven provinces in Sri Lanka, and the outcome of the 
project  will  be  improved  local  infrastructure  and  services  delivered  effectively  by  local 
authorities.  The  project  will  be  implemented  in  less-developed  areas  in  seven  provinces, 
excluding the Northern and Eastern provinces. 

Outputs 

The project will have the following outputs. 

C. 
 
12. 
 
13. 
Output  1:  Improved  local  infrastructure  and  basic  services  delivery.  In  this 
component,  social  and  economic  infrastructure  in  less-developed  areas  will  be  improved  by 
participating local authorities, in line with the second pillar of the sector development plan. The 
project  will  adopt  a  bottom–up,  demand-driven  approach,  whereby  priority  subprojects  will  be 
identified,  proposed,  implemented,  and  managed  by  local  authorities.  About  100  pradeshiya 
sabhas selected by the government will  first have to submit a reform plan approved through a 
council resolution, which will be reviewed and confirmed by the MLGPC in consultation with the 
provincial councils to ensure that the minimum reform requirements are met (footnote 10). Then 
they will be qualified for the provision of a capital grant under this component for infrastructure 
improvement.  Each  reform  plan  will  present  the  clear  commitment  of  the  local  authority  to  (i) 
improve  service  delivery  with  particular  emphasis  on  the  local  environmental  improvement;  (ii) 
streamline  taxation,  licensing,  and  approval  systems  and  processes;19 (iii)  ensure  the  effective 
management  of  the  assets,  including  those  to  be  created  under  the  project;  and  (iv)  improve 
systems and management. The implementation of each reform plan will be closely monitored by 
the project management unit (PMU) in the MLGPC and subproject coordination units (SPCUs) 
in  provincial  councils.  The  successful  implementation  of  reforms  under  such  reform  plans  is  a 
key factor in determining budgetary support for local authorities. 

 

 

14. 
Eligible  subprojects  include  (i)  environmental  infrastructure  such  as  water  supply  and 
sanitation  (including  sewerage),  drainage,  and  solid  waste  management;  (ii)  economic 
infrastructure  such  as  roads  and  bridges  (including  suspension  bridges);  (iii)  public  health 
infrastructure such as maternity and health-care centers; and (iv) other local authority facilities 
such  as  public  markets.  To  strengthen  the  focus  of  the  project,  other  facilities  under  the 
responsibility  of  local  authorities,  such  as  local  authority  office  buildings,  libraries,  and 
crematoriums,  are  generally  not  accepted  and  may  be  approved  only  under  special 
circumstances  and  if  clearly  justified.  Subprojects  will  be  screened  initially  by  the  SPCUs  to 
ensure  conformity  with  the  provincial  physical  development  plan  and  subproject  selection 
criteria  before  they  will  be  endorsed  by  the  PMU.20 The  PMU  will  engage  several  teams  of 
design and supervision consultants to ensure the quality of work. 
 
15.

component  will  assist  the  implementation  of  the  first  pillar  of  the  sector  development  plan 
(reform  advancement)  by  supporting  (i)  local  authorities’  institutionalizing  business  process 
reengineering,  including  the  implementation  of  relevant  bylaws  and  regulations,  with  capacity 
development  support  provided  to  the  local  authorities, 21  and  (ii)  the  development  of  an  IT

support the smooth and effective implementation and operation of the project. The PMU  in the

Training  programs  will  be  provided  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  provincial  and  local 
governments to effectively plan development and efficiently administer local development.

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  

 
20. 
The capacity development TA for Local Government Service Enhancement will support 
local government policy reform, and its output will be (i) recommendations for business process 

 7 

 
reengineering proposed for improved and more efficient service delivery in local authorities and 
(ii) capacity development support to undertake local business process reengineering. The main 
activities  will  be  (i)  proposing  business  process  reengineering through  a  review  of  current  tax, 
licensing,  and  approval  systems  and  processes  in  local  authorities;  (ii)  drafting  bylaws  and 
regulations  governing  local  governments  to  support  business  process  reengineering;  and  (iii) 
supporting  the  preparation  and  implementation  of  IT  system  development  in  local  authorities. 
The TA is estimated to cost $640,000 equivalent, of which $540,000 equivalent will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will 
finance  the  remaining  $100,000  equivalent.  The  executing  agency  for  the  TA  is  the  MLGPC. 
The TA  will  undertake  the  analytical  work  and help  develop  institutional capacity  to  implement 
component 2 of the project.24 
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical  

Economic and Financial 

A. 
 
Feasibility studies of sample subprojects undertaken in Kolonna and Neluwa pradeshiya 
21. 
sabhas  during  project  preparation  confirmed  technical  viability,  with  due  consideration  of  local 
capacity  to  undertake  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M).  Complex  water  supply  subprojects 
that  go  beyond  the  capacity  of  local  authorities  will  not  be  implemented  under  the  project. 
Technology  selection  prioritizes  the  least-cost  option,  taking  into  account  O&M  costs,  for 
nonrevenue-generating subprojects, and training will be carried out as necessary to ensure local 
authorities’ sustainable operation of subproject outputs. 
 
B. 
 
Public  investment  under  the  project  is  justified  because  (i)  natural  monopolies  are 
22. 
involved  (e.g.,  piped  water  supply  and  sewerage);  (ii)  services  and  benefits  are  public  goods 
(e.g.,  roads  and  drainage);  and  (iii)  integrated  and  coordinated  management  is  required.  The 
infrastructure  to  be  developed  under  the  project  is  to  meet  the  basic  needs  of  citizens  in 
participating  local  authorities.  The  economic  analysis  of  subprojects  was  conducted  for  three 
sample  subprojects  in  water  supply,  roads,  and  solid  waste  management.  Estimates  of  the 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  sample  subprojects  range from  17.1%  to  22.7%,  indicating 
sufficiently high economic return. The results are most sensitive to reduced benefits but robust 
against other downside risks, including increased capital cost, increased O&M cost, and delay in 
project implementation. Moreover, underestimation of the economic returns is likely because the 
subprojects have benefits that are not easily captured in numerical values.  
 
Some  subprojects  such  as  roads  and  drainage  improvement  do  not  generate  cash 
23. 
revenues,  while  others,  including  water  supply  and  public  markets,  generate  cash  revenues. 
Therefore,  financial  analysis  was  conducted  for  two  sample  subprojects  in  water  supply  and 
public markets. The financial internal rates of return were estimated at 3.4% for the water supply 
subproject  and  12.1%  for  the  public  market  subproject,  which  compared  favorably  with  the 
weighted  average  cost  of  capital,  estimated  at  0.9%.  For  nonrevenue-generating  subprojects, 
the analysis focused on local authorities’ financial capacity to meet the recurrent costs required 
to operate and maintain the developed physical assets in a sustainable manner. The projected 
financial  position  of  sample  local  authorities  confirmed  their  financial  capacity  to  meet  O&M 
costs and other requirements to sustain service delivery. When the PMU reviews the subproject 
requests from local authorities, it will assess the capacity and commitment of local authorities to 
allocate adequate O&M budget to sustain service delivery.

C. 

Governance 

24. 
An  assessment  of  financial  management  and  procurement  capacity  undertaken  during 
project  preparation  indicates  that  the  MLGPC  can  manage  loan  proceeds  for  project 
implementation.  The  PMU  and  the  SPCUs  have  experience  in  financial  management  and 
procurement  in  accordance  with  ADB  requirements  and  have  a  satisfactory  track  record  from 
the LGIIP. Procurement for civil works and equipment will be handled at the provincial level  to 
reduce  procurement  risks,  as  SPCUs  have  higher  capacity  and  more  experience  than  local 
authorities. Transparency in procurement, financing, and other matters will be maximized under 
the  project  through  such  measures  as  the  PMU’s  developing  a  project  website  to  disclose 
information  on  the  project  to  reduce  corruption  risk  and  improve  governance.  Each  local 
authority’s  preparation  and  implementation  of  the  reform  plan,  which  includes  strengthening 
financial  discipline  and  enhancing  citizens’  participation  in  the  local  authority’s  administrative 
matters, will help improve the accountability of local authorities. 

 
25. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are 
described in the project administration manual (footnote 23). 

 
Poverty and Social 

D. 

The  project  is  classified as  effective gender mainstreaming. While  women in Sri  Lanka 
26. 
generally  have  higher  status  than  women  in  other  developing  countries  in  South  Asia  and 
elsewhere  in  terms  of  access  to  education  and  health-care  services,  many  women  are 
disadvantaged  owing  to  poor  roads,  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  other  public  services, 
particularly  in  less-developed  areas  of  the  country.  Limited  access  to  safe  drinking  water 
requires  household  members,  primarily  women  and  children,  to  spend  considerable  time  and 
effort  on  fetching  water.  Inadequate  and  poor-quality  roads  limit  poor  communities’  access  to 
markets, health-care centers, and schools and create safety and security issues for women and 
girls.  Subprojects  identified  in a participatory  and  inclusive manner  will  address the  immediate 
needs  of  communities,  including  women.  A  gender  action  plan  will  be  implemented  to  ensure 
inclusiveness and address the different needs of women and vulnerable groups. By focusing its 
support  to  less-developed  areas  of  the  country,  the  project  will  help  redress  geographical 
inequality and contribute to balanced regional development. 

 

E. 

Safeguards 

The  project  is  category  B  for  environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous 
27. 
peoples.  The  subproject  selection  criteria  limit  negative  impacts  through  avoidance  and 
minimization. Subprojects will have positive environmental benefits, improving local authorities’ 
environment  and  public  health.  Potential  adverse  environmental  impacts  are  mostly  related  to 
construction  and  are  temporary.  No  significant  involuntary  resettlement  or  indigenous  peoples 
impacts are anticipated. 

 
28.

indigenous  peoples  planning  framework  have  been  prepared  for  the  project.25 Consistent  with 
the safeguards frameworks, three initial environmental examinations were prepared for sample 
subprojects.  They  include  environmental  management  plans  that  will  ensure  adequate 
mitigation  of  adverse  environmental  impacts.  None  of  the  sample  subprojects  has  involuntary 
resettlement  or  indigenous  peoples  impacts.  The  project  improves  on  implementation 
arrangements  for  the  ongoing  LGIIP  and  will  further  build  the  executing  agency’s  capacity  for
